channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudis Report Deadly Border Clash With Infiltrators From Iraq
item.description: Four assailants fired automatic weapons and detonated suicide belts in a confrontation that left them and three Saudi border guards dead.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: 2 Dead as Aircraft Bombs Greek Tanker in Libyan Port
item.description: An unidentified warplane bombed a Greek-owned tanker ship at the Libyan port of Darna on Sunday, killing two crew members and injuring two more, Greek authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Huge Ship Carrying Cars Deliberately Grounded Off Coast of England
item.description: The 57,000-ton Hoegh Osaka was run aground on Bramble Bank, a well-marked sandbank off the port of Southampton, to prevent it from capsizing after it began to list.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Indonesia Cracks Down on Aviation Sector After AirAsia Crash
item.description: The Transportation Ministry said all AirAsia flights to Singapore would be banned until after an investigation into whether Flight 8501 had all required permits was complete.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Letter From America: Workplaces Remain Averse to Flexibility
item.description: Despite the evidence, people seeking more flexible workplaces and jobs still often find themselves penalized.
item.dc:creator: By ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: Gunmen Kill 3 Saudi Guards Along Border With Iraq
item.description: Four gunmen attacked a Saudi security patrol near the Iraqi border early Monday, killing three soldiers and wounding at least three more, the kingdom's Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: After Ban on Beef From Europe, U.S. Gives Green Light to Ireland
item.description: Ireland has met American safety rules, becoming the first European country to come off a ban that was imposed after an outbreak of mad cow disease in the late 1990s.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:description: United States authorities imposed bans on beef imports after an epidemic of mad cow disease across Europe in the late 1990s.

item.title: 2 Opposition Activists Die in Clashes in Bangladesh
item.description: The deaths occurred despite a nationwide tightening of security in anticipation of violence on the first anniversary of the governing party’s re-election.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Invoking Shanghai Stampede, College Stirs Outrage
item.description: The university in Xi’an, which had banned Christmas celebrations, published a statement titled, “The unfortunate Shanghai holiday stampede tragedy confirms that our school’s position on holiday management is indisputably correct.”
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: A boy prepared to pray on Saturday for the victims of the New Year's Eve stampede in Shanghai.

item.title: China Issues Complaint After North Korean Defector Is Said to Kill 4
item.description: A soldier fleeing the North killed the Chinese citizens in late December during a robbery attempt, according to a Chinese official and various reports.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Taiwan’s Ex-Leader Released From Prison on Medical Parole
item.description: Chen Shui-bian, the former president of Taiwan who was sentenced to 20 years in prison, suffers from a series of medical conditions including depression, brain atrophy and Parkinsonism.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Chen Shui-bian, with his son, Chen Chih-chung, waved to supporters after being released from prison on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Graft Offensive May Expose Something More Vile in China: Factions
item.description: A recent burst of official Chinese commentaries asserting that corruption scandals have exposed a “culture of cliques” points to the deeper tremors detonated by President Xi Jinping’s campaign to clean house.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Paramilitary police stand guard under a portrait of Mao Zedong outside the Forbidden City at Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Jeremy Wallace on China’s Rush to Urbanize
item.description: The author discusses how China has avoided the instability that urbanization has brought to many other countries around the world.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Indian Rape Case Echoes Claims of Tourists as Prey
item.description: Five men were arrested after a tourist said they robbed her and held her for days in a village where two of them raped her, charges that echo complaints from other tourists and tourism officials.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Sudder Street in Kolkata, India, is popular with foreign backpackers. A Japanese tourist claims she met a tour guide there who, with four accomplices, later kidnapped, robbed and raped her.

item.title: Pangti Journal: Falcon Hunters Become Fervent Preservationists
item.description: A campaign to stop the mass killing of migrating Amur falcons has turned the people of Pangti, India, into stewards of the birds they once slaughtered.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Millions of migrating Amur falcons passed unharmed through India in October and November after villagers in Pangti ordered a ban on hunting.

item.title: Pope Names 15 New Cardinals Reflective of Diversity of the Faithful
item.description: Many came from countries that have never had a cardinal, like Myanmar, Tonga and the Cape Verde islands, and were reflective of the Roman Catholic Church’s growth in Asia and Africa.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis said the bishops and archbishops represent “every continent, to manifest the indissoluble links” between Rome and the churches around the world.

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Bombing by Al Qaeda Kills at Least 6 People
item.description: Al Qaeda bombed an office of the Shiite Houthi rebels south of the capital on Sunday, killing six Houthis and wounding 31, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Suicide Bomber Attacks Troops in Capital
item.description: A suicide car bomber detonated his explosives near a convoy of elite Somali troops known as the Alpha Group in the capital, Mogadishu, killing at least four people, a Somali police officer said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Militants Overrun Military Base, Officials Say
item.description: Islamist militants have overrun an army base in the remote northeastern town of Baga, security officials said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: Police Ban Rallies as Tensions Increase
item.description: The police banned all rallies in Dhaka, the capital, on Sunday and prevented a top opposition leader from leaving her office.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
